pre.oneLine: AuthorizationService (NA-East) is experiencing sustained elevated p95 latency above baseline.
pre.proof:
Detection Sources:
Monitoring (Datadog)
User Report (Amazon, Delta Airlines)
Automation (xMatters Sev-1 rule)

Evidence Collected:
Metrics screenshots from Datadog
xMatters high-priority alert
Merchant emails (Amazon, Delta)
Internal Teams chatter confirming latency and 504s
ServiceNow auto-Sev1 ticket
pre.objectPrefill: AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).
pre.healthy:
Authorization p95 latency ~95–150ms

Timeout rate < 0.3%

No sustained regional deviation

Major merchants reporting normal operation

Health checks passing within expected thresholds
pre.now: p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.

impact.now:
Merchants in NA-East reporting payment delays/timeouts

Amazon retry rate 5–7%

Delta kiosks unable to process payments

MerchantGateway experiencing elevated 504 responses

Increased abandonment in retail checkouts
impact.future:
Retry storms may propagate load and degrade other regions (NA-West, SA)

SLO/SLA breach likely within minutes

Potential throttling by downstream issuers

Escalation to global merchant base (churn & reputational risk)

On-call fatigue and SME overload if the incident expands
impact.time:
Impact is active now

Expected to worsen within 5–10 minutes if no containment initiated

Merchant dissatisfaction already emerging

ops.containDesc: Pause non-critical MerchantGateway transactions impacting Auth until traffic stabilizes. Validate with SME before execution.

table.band: WHAT — Define the problem precisely (Object & Deviation).

table.q: WHAT — Specific Object/Thing is having the “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.”
table.is: AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).
table.no:
AuthService — NA-West
AuthService — EU shard
FraudEdge precheck service
MerchantGateway service
Redis cluster
Network transport layer
table.di: NA-East Authorization uses a different logic branch due to region-specific config.
table.ch: Region-specific override for adaptive risk scoring was enabled yesterday afternoon, but only for NA-East.

table.q: WHAT — Specific Deviation does the “AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).” have?
table.is: p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.
table.no:
Authorization service is down
Authorization service is returning zero responses
Authorization errors are increasing across regions
FraudEdge latency is elevated
MerchantGateway latency is elevated

table.band: WHERE — Locate the problem (geography/topology and on the object).

table.q: WHERE — is the “AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).” geographically/topology when the “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.” occurs?
table.no:
NA-West
EU region
South America region
Sandbox / non-production
table.di: NA-East is uniquely under promo-concentrated load, making it the only region able to trigger the new logic branch.
table.ch: Traffic steering policy shifted heavier Amazon promo traffic to NA-East earlier this week.

table.q: WHERE — On the “AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).” is the “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.” observed?
table.is:
Authorization path within AuthService.
Points where MerchantGateway calls AuthService (responses originating from AuthService in NA-East).
table.no:
TokenService path
FraudEdge decision path
Redis lookup path
Kafka publish/subscribe layers

table.q: WHEN — Was the “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.” First observed for “AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).”
table.no:
10:01 AM Dev Datadog annotation
Earlier EU event referenced in Slack
9:55 AM MerchantGateway config push

table.q: WHEN — Since the first occurrence has “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.” been logged? What Pattern?
table.is:
Sustained elevation for several minutes (3–4+).
Not intermittent.
table.no:
Periodic pattern
Improving trend
Limited to a single AZ
Alternating across regions

table.q: WHEN — Describe using words When the “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.” was first seen
table.is:
During active authorization traffic.
During morning merchant peak (Amazon promo surge).
table.no:
During a deploy window
During planned maintenance
During a failover event
table.di: The deviation starts when the traffic threshold is crossed, not when the deploy or config change happened.
table.ch: Threshold parameters updated at 9:58; threshold crossed at 10:03.

table.band: EXTENT — How big is it? Magnitude, count, scope, trend.

table.q: EXTENT — What is the population or size of “AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).” affected?
table.is:
All AuthService nodes in NA-East.
All AZs in NA-East.
table.no:
Nodes in NA-West
Nodes in EU
Nodes in staging/sandbox

table.q: EXTENT — What is the size of a single “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.”?
table.no:
Multi-second total stalls (e.g., 3–5 seconds unresponsive)
Total outage (zero responses)
CPU/memory exhaustion

table.q: EXTENT — How many “p95 authorization latency is elevated to 500–700ms and sustained beyond normal behavior.” are occuring on each “AuthService — NA-East regional shard (Authorization path only).”?
table.is:
Continuous elevated latency across all NA-East nodes.
Present across multiple merchant flows (Amazon, Delta).
table.no:
Single-node issue
Single-merchant issue
Short-lived blip

causes.suspect: Adaptive risk scoring logic in NA-East Authorization path
causes.summaryText: We suspect Adaptive risk scoring logic in NA-East Authorization path is adds overhead under threshold-triggered conditions. This could lead to load causing latency to spike.

WHAT — Specific Object/Thing is having t.note: The region-specific config override exists only in NA-East Authorization path (matches IS). No other region or service uses that branch (matches IS NOT).

WHAT — Specific Deviation does the {OBJE.note: Extra processing overhead from the logic branch explains latency elevation without causing outages or multi-region failures.

WHERE — is the {OBJECT} geographically/t.note: Region-specific override applies to NA-East only (matches IS). Other regions do not use override or hit threshold (matches IS NOT).

WHERE — On the {OBJECT} is the {DEVIATIO.note: Only the Authorization handler uses the adaptive scoring logic; other handlers do not. Exact alignment.

WHEN — Was the {DEVIATION} First observe.note: Threshold for adaptive scoring activated only once traffic crossed at 10:03. Prior times show no effect (aligned to IS NOT).

WHEN — Since the first occurrence has {D.note: Flag logic would increase compute consistently under load; region-wide config makes pattern uniform across AZs.

WHEN — Describe using words When the {DE.note: Threshold-based scoring triggers under high traffic (IS). It is not tied to deploy/maintenance/failover (IS NOT).

EXTENT — What is the population or size.note: Region-wide override applied to every node in NA-East. Other regions not affected.

EXTENT — What is the size of a single {D.note: Feature overhead produces sub-second increases, not multisecond stalls or outages.

EXTENT — How many {DEVIATION} are occuri.note: Region-wide threshold logic affects all AZs and all merchants routed through NA-East. No contradictions.

causes.summaryText: We suspect MerchantGateway retry configuration because of too aggressive. This could lead to amplifies latency during authorization degradation.

WHAT — Specific Object/Thing is having t.note: Retries could amplify latency on the auth path only if AuthService is already slow (assumption required). Cannot explain NA-East-specific config difference.

WHAT — Specific Deviation does the {OBJE.note: Retries can push latency to 500–700ms only if upstream (AuthService) slowdown begins first.

WHERE — is the {OBJECT} geographically/t.note: MGW retry behavior is global; only NA-East sees impact if NA-East responds slower than other regions. Assumption needed.

WHERE — On the {OBJECT} is the {DEVIATIO.note: MGW retries affect only paths calling AuthService; but cannot independently explain why only Authorization handler is slow. Requires assumption.

WHEN — Was the {DEVIATION} First observe.note: Retries spike at exactly 10:03 because AuthService slowed. This fits only if another cause degraded AuthService first.

WHEN — Since the first occurrence has {D.note: Retry storms can produce sustained latency (fits IS).

WHEN — Describe using words When the {DE.note: Retries align to promo surge only if AuthService degraded at the same time.

EXTENT — What is the population or size.note: Would affect all NA-East nodes if MGW retries hit all endpoints uniformly; requires assumption.

EXTENT — What is the size of a single {D.note: Retry amplification can produce 500–700ms range, but requires AuthService to be marginally slow first.

EXTENT — How many {DEVIATION} are occuri.note: Continuous retries align with continuous upstream latency if AuthService remains slow.

causes.accusation: intermittently resolves to a cross-region shard under load
causes.impact: the round-trip time delay to request and get a response from the remote shard increases latency
causes.summaryText: We suspect Redis routing is intermittently resolves to a cross-region shard under load. This could lead to the round-trip time delay to request and get a response from the remote shard increases latency.

WHAT — Specific Object/Thing is having t.note: Redis misrouting would affect TokenService, FraudEdge, and other paths — but IS says they’re normal. Contradiction.

WHAT — Specific Deviation does the {OBJE.note: Cross-region Redis calls cause multi-second stalls or intermittent spikes — NOT uniform 500–700ms elevation.

WHERE — is the {OBJECT} geographically/t.note: Redis routing bugs rarely hit an entire region uniformly; would show uneven AZ impacts, contradicting IS.

WHERE — On the {OBJECT} is the {DEVIATIO.note: Redis routing would affect multiple paths beyond Authorization (contradicting IS NOT entries).

WHEN — Was the {DEVIATION} First observe.note: Redis issues do not align precisely with a 10:03 AM threshold event; mismatch with IS.

WHEN — Since the first occurrence has {D.note: Redis problems are intermittent or jittery — contradicts sustained pattern.

WHEN — Describe using words When the {DE.note: Redis issues do not correlate to promo surges (IS), nor to deploy/maintenance windows (IS NOT). No alignment.

EXTENT — What is the population or size.note: Cross-region Redis calls would not hit all NA-East nodes uniformly — contradicts IS.

EXTENT — What is the size of a single {D.note: Remote shard resolution would exceed 1–3 seconds or time out entirely — contradicts IS 500–700ms envelope.

EXTENT — How many {DEVIATION} are occuri.note: Redis issues would be uneven, merchant-specific, or node-specific — contradicts continuous all-node pattern.

items.label: Bridge etiquette, roles, and guidelines outlined
Last changes, monitoring, and dependencies investigated
Possible causes evaluated and distinctions identified

items.summary: Verify latency across all AZs in NA-East (are all AZs affected or only one?)
Check regional parity (NA-West, EU-Central): confirm this is isolated.
Retrieve last-known-good window for AuthService from Datadog.
Gather the exact merchant impact metrics (retry %, timeouts, abandonment).
Check FraudEdge queues to confirm not contributing.
Validate Redis routing update status in case SMEs attempt to blame it.
Confirm recent MerchantGateway config change timing vs spike onset.
Coordinate with MCNO to determine whether a Broadscope is now required.
Confirm actual timeout error codes (504 vs 408 vs 429).
